content.webTitle: Is there a doctor in the house? Not necessarily for aged care

fields.headline: Is there a doctor in the house? Not necessarily for aged care
fields.bodyText: When Isabela’s mother moved into an aged care home, it was because she needed more support than it was possible to provide in her own home. She had some complex medical needs, and no one knew that better than her GP. But moving into residential care meant the end of that relationship. “They said, ‘This is her doctor now’,” Isabela says. “But it’s just one doctor, once a week, and just for a couple of hours in the morning. “You have a really good GP that knows all about you, and then you don’t see them any more.” Difficult decisions GPs provided more than 5.5m Medicare services in residential aged care facilities in 2018-19, according to the Health of the Nation report from the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP). Much of the work goes unpaid, the RACGP says. “What you don’t see is the time out of practice,” RACGP president Dr Harry Nespolon recently told the Royal Commission into Aged Care Quality and Safety. “A lot of these consultations are done out of hours because it’s the only way it makes any economic sense - if you leave your practice during the day you’re not seeing patients that you would normally see.” Dr Morton Rawlin does exactly that, responding to calls from nursing home staff, attending to acute injuries, and visiting patients regularly - out of hours. He is conducting a review into the medical care of aged care residents and is chair of the RACGP Silver Book committee, tasked with updating the college’s clinical guide for aged care. Medicare covers items such as chronic disease management but not things such as the extra time it takes to address complex multiple conditions outside the practice, Dr Rawlin says. Dealing with administrative or service coordination issues and communicating with nursing staff are also outside Medicare. There is a significant amount of unremunerated services provided by GPs for patients in RACFs (residential aged care facilities). Photograph: Dean Mitchell / Getty Images. On top of that, GPs sometimes travel long distances to keep in contact with patients who have had to move to facilities many kilometres away. “The GP has to make a decision [whether to keep seeing a patient],” Dr Rawlin says. “Sometimes it’s just not possible.” Dr Nespolon told the royal commission that GPs can feel they have “abandoned” their patients. “You generally feel that … ” he said. “It’s about that relationship which may have been going on for many decades and now is lost because of the economics of the situation.” A little bit broken Currently, one in three GP consultations is with someone aged 65 or over, and that number is expected to more than double. This age group will make up 22% of the population by 2057, the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare says. Research shows that GPs are both vital in providing the necessary healthcare, and the most cost-effective option. Ideally, people would live independently as long as possible with the appropriate level of in-home support, only moving into residential care if their needs become unmanageable. Dr Rawlin says: “The aged care royal commission would suggest [that system] is a little bit broken at the moment. “We haven’t kept pace with the demand for services, particularly in the home, and as such a lot of people have moved into the aged care residential sector, where things have, to some degree, been driven by costs, and sometimes the care has not worked as well as it should.” What’s the way forward? “Aged care and multi-morbidity is an area which requires good and well-educated GPs to be involved; it’s very challenging work,” Dr Rawlin says. “The biggest challenges are the fact that the sector is growing significantly and quickly [and] making sure that we have consistent standards, with well-trained staff, in adequate numbers, so that the care needs for our patients are well served.” That’s the aim, regardless of the model of care. “Not every GP is the same, not every nursing home is the same - there is no one-size-fits-all,” Dr Rawlin says. Dr Rawlin believes the latest edition of the Silver Book can be a useful resource for anyone working towards that goal in the aged care sector. The college is also developing clinical standards to improve the way GPs and aged care facilities work together, streamlining some of the processes that have sometimes created barriers against the provision of care to residents. “It will make it a little bit easier to know that they’re doing the right thing, to try and demystify things a little bit, and make sure that people get consistency in the quality of their care,” Dr Rawlin says. The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP) is Australia’s largest professional general practice organisation - our mission is to improve the health and wellbeing of all people in Australia by supporting GPs, general practice registrars and medical students.
